Award.AwardTitle: DDRI: Intervention Effects in Raising and Control: Evidence from Spanish-speaking children data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
An important objective of language acquisition research is to understand why certain grammatical constructions take longer to acquire than others. This research proposal investigates two constructions that are not fully mastered until school age: raising verbs such as 'seem', e.g. "Mary seems (to John) to be smart"; and control verbs such as 'promise', e.g. "Mary promised (John) to be cautious". Although semantically and structurally different, these verbs show interesting similarities: i) both involve an interpretative dependency between the subject in the upper clause, 'Mary', and an unpronounced subject in the lower clause -- Mary is the smart/cautious one, and ii) in both cases there is an argument intervening between the two dependent elements, '(to) John'.

Despite the extensive literature on the acquisition of these constructions in English, there is no consensus on why they are late to develop. One prominent explanation holds that the delay is due to the presence of the intervening argument, either for grammatical or processing reasons. Interestingly, in Spanish an intervener is possible with 'prometer' (as with 'promise') but not with 'parecer' (in contrast to 'seem'). Therefore a comparison of Spanish and English acquisition could be extremely helpful is evaluating the 'intervention' account. This experimental study is the first to investigate the development of raising and control in Spanish-speaking children.

Three comprehension experiments will be conducted on each language in order to determine whether the protracted development of these constructions comes from a common underlying source, namely intervention effects. Two additional experiments designed to measure linguistic processing and memory span will be used to determine whether children's difficulties with these constructions are due to a non-adult syntactic representation, or due to verbal working memory limitations. Discriminating between grammatical or processing deficits has the potential of aiding in the progress of other related domains, such as speech therapy or computational linguistics. This project will also provide research opportunities for undergraduate students, which is expected to have a direct impact on their research education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
An important objective of language acquisition research is to understand why certain grammatical constructions take longer to acquire than others. This research study investigated two constructions that are not fully mastered until school age: ‘raising’ verbs such as ‘seem’ (1) and ‘control’ verbs such as ‘promise’ (2)

(1) Mary seems to John _ to be nice.

(2) Mary promised John _ to be nice

 Although semantically and structurally different, these verb constructions show interesting similarities: i) both involve an interpretative dependency between the subject in the upper clause, ‘Mary’, and an unpronounced subject in the lower clause, – Mary is the nice one. ii) In both cases there is an argument intervening between the two dependent elements, i.e., ‘(to) John’.

Despite the extensive literature on the acquisition of these constructions in English, there is no consensus on why they are late to develop.  One prominent explanation holds that the delay is due to the presence of the intervening argument (‘John’ above), and that this is related to children’s grammatical or processing deficiencies. Interestingly, in Spanish an intervener is possible with ‘prometer’ (as with ‘promise’) but never with the functional verb ‘parecer’ (in contrast to ‘seem’). Therefore a comparison of English and Spanish acquisition could be extremely helpful is evaluating the ‘intervention’ account. This experimental study was the first to investigate the development of raising and control in Spanish-speaking children.  

We found that while English-speaking 6-year-olds still show difficulties with ‘seem’ and ‘promise’, Spanish-speaking 6-year-olds only show difficulties with prometer ‘promise’. Contrastively, they do well with parecer ‘seem’ by the time they are only 4-years old. These results confirm that the protracted development of these constructions in English must be related to the intervening noun. Additionally, we found that English-speaking children have difficulties with ‘seem’ even when the intervening argument is not expressed, suggesting that children always mentally represent it, inducing intervention effects whether it is expressed or not.

Finally, we addressed the question of whether these intervention effects are due to an underdeveloped grammar or an underdeveloped processing system. In order to investigate this question we administered two independent measures of short-term memory and verbal processing capacity. We concluded that both grammatical and processing deficiencies are behind children’s difficulties with ‘seem’ and ‘promise’. Specifically, we found two subgroups of children. Those that consistently gave an incorrect response do not have the appropriate adult grammatical system. They still have a rule system that bans dependencies across interveners, and in this group, verbal processing capacity score did not predict their performance in the linguistic tasks, i.e., some children had superb verbal processing capacity and yet they did not perform well with ‘seem’ or ‘promise’. On the other hand, there was a subgroup of children who performed better, or even on a par with adults. In this subgroup, verbal processing capacity did predict their performance with ‘seem’ and ‘promise’. We hypothesize that these children have an adult-like grammatical rule system, but some may still not have the necessary processing resources to derive the meaning of these interrupted dependencies appropriately.

This study was the first to reconcile and provide evidence for both grammatical and processing accounts. Identifying the relative weight of grammatical or processing deficits has the potential of aiding in the progress of other related domains in the future, such as speech therapy or computational linguistics.
